Magazines for those interested in Z80-Family

AFAIK there aren't (m)any heavily Z80 oriented magazine left, but from time to time there are articles with Z80 related stuff or with stuff adaptable to Z80 based designs.
If you know of more (in whatever language), or if you have URLs of sites archiving old (or new) magazines which may be of interest for Z80 users, please tell me.

Table-of-Contents
  • Magazines in English
  • Magazines in German
  • Articles in English
  • Articles in German

BYTE Articles

  • Title: The Z80 in Parallel
    Subtitle: An arbitration circuit to coordinate shared memory accesses between two Z80 processors. 
    Issue: July 1978
Page: 60
Author: Bob Loewer

CCI Articles

  • Title: Silicon Update
    Subtitle: Whither Zilog? -- A Roller Coaster on the Back of the Z80 
    Issue: 14 Apr/May 1990
Page: 78
Author: Tom Cantrell
  • Title: HD647180X -- A New 8-Bit Microcontroller
    Subtitle: Embedded Controllers Get Respect 
    Issue: 8 Apr/May 1989
Page: 52
Author: Tom Cantrell
Abstract: While the state-of-the-art marches toward 32 bits, 8-bit
	microcontrollers keep getting more powerful. The HD647180X is the
	latest integrated controller built on the foundation of the proven
	Z80.
CCI_index: HD647180X 8-bit Microcontroller
  • Title: Silicon Update
    Subtitle: I'm 18.432 -- and I Like It 
    Issue: 29 Oct/Nov 1992
Page: 80
Author: Tom Cantrell
Abstract: Some people just can't get enough horsepower out of their
	processors, and Tome is certainly one of them. Zilog's newest speed
	demon runs the faithful Z180 (HD64180) up to 18.432 MHz and beyond.
CCI_index: Z180 Zilog at 18.432 MHz
  • Title: Silicon Update
    Subtitle: Flight of the Phoenix 
    Issue: 72 July 1996
Page: 74
Author: Tom Cantrell
Abstract: Zilog has risen from its ashes. It offers the S180 processor along
	with an evaluation/emulation board. Ironically, it's a chip off the old
	Z80, CTC, PIO, and SIO, the cornerstones of Zilog's glory in the 1970s.
  • Title: Updating a Classic: the Z80380 Microprocessor 
    Issue: 67 Feb 1996
Page: 12
Author: Monte Dalrymple
Abstract: After reviewing the Z80's popularity, Monte introduces the Z380, a
	new chip offering a full complement of 16-bit data manipulations and
	enough 32-bit instructions to handle the new 32-bit addresses.
  • Title: A Simple RS-485 Network
    Subtitle: Exploit the Nine-Bit Serial Communication Modes of the 8051, 8096BH, 68HC11, 68HC05, and Z180 Microcontroller Families 
    Issue: 21 Jun/Jul 1991
Page: 38
Author: Jim Butler
Abstract: RS-485 is a perfect standard for networking controllers. A solid
	strategy for network design makes the job easier, and the result more
	powerful.
CCI_index: RS-485 Network for 8051, 8096BH, 68HC11,68HC05, Z180
  • Title: Power-Line-Based Computer Control
    Subtitle: The X-10 PL513 Power Line Interface Module 
    Issue: 3 May/Jun 1988
Page: 4
Author: Ken Davidson
Download: X10BC180.Z80 X10BCC52.ARC X10IBMPC.ARC
CCI_index: X-10  PL513 Power Line Interface Module
  • Title: The X-10 TW523 Two-Way Power Line Interface
    Subtitle: A step toward closed-loop power line control 
    Issue: 5 Sep/Oct 1988
Page: 34
Author: Ken Davidson
Download: X10RCVR.Z80
CCI_index: X-10 TW523 Two-way Power Line Interface

    Issue: Sep 1997
Page: 34
Author: Holger Petersen
Contents: It takes 512 bytes of code of which 256 are a table.
